monogr.title: Egluryn phraethineb. sebh, dosparth ar retoreg, vn oʿr saith gelbhydhyd, yn dysculhuniaith ymadrodh, aʿi pherthynassau
monogr.author: Perry, Henry

div.l: IF of their Thalmud Iewes made much, if Turks their Alcoran boast,
If Priests of Egypt did commend their Memphia Chronicles most:
Then Brittaines may their Bardi brag, and yeeld them gwerdon due;
which pend their praise, advanc'd their fame, & did their names renue.
Had Bookes not crowned Rome with fame, and set their Cæsars out;
Of Romane state, and Cæsars name, small praise had beene (no doubt)
If Caldeans by Berosus are, extold to loftie spheares,
And Persians praise by Ctesius pend, to feede the Persians eares:
Then Perry presse and pleade for praise, who left no praise vnsought:
And now to praise his Country more, a worke of praise he wrought.
He Rhetoricke taught; the Atticke Tonge, with Kings in Court to talke,
He broght such flowers from Phrigia's fields, as furnisht Cambers walk.
He quickened Cambria halfe being dead, and gaue to Cambria Marts:
He shadow'd Greece in Cambria soile, & broght frō Greece their Arts
Dardania is by him renude, and Troy revivde againe;
To giue a glasse to glory lost, it is no losse but gaine.
The Hebrue Rabbins deeme no man sit, their Hebrue bookes to reed;
And Greeks thoght barbarus al the world, but such as Greece did breed.
But Iewes Iudea lost thereby, and Greeks their Greece haue lost;
Now Brittaines bath in Brutus blisse, in auncient Albions Coast.
VVhere old Anchises broode did breede, where Dardans stocke remaine,
VVhere Troians sayld, where Bryttaines dwelt, to Queen Eliza's raign.
Thus Perry prou'd and pend his Booke, and puts his booke in viewe;
To see what may be seene or sayd, of him that wrote so true.
